column2: And the manner of taking to the seeker's renunciation marked by one staff has been prescribed for tridandins thus: ‘These staffs, water-pot, begging-bowl with the suspension-strainer, topknot, and sacred-thread, all these to be offered to the bhürloka i.e. the earth, reciting the formula: “oblation to bhūh' and throwing them into waterJĪVAN MUKTIVIVEKA and seek the Self'. Then vidvat-sannyasa, the knower's renunciation, which is the end of the former , is described thus: 'The paramahamsa is precisely he who is like a new-born baby, whose mind is free from the effects of the pairs of opposites, devoid of all possessions, who is firmly established in the way of Brahman i.e. the final emancipation, whose mind is free from all desires, who, just to maintain life without any obligation, goes about begging at the prescribed time, using his belly as the begging bowl, and is unperturbed whether he gets it or not, without a fixed dwelling, lives in anywhere from a derelict house, a temple, a hay-stack, under a tree, in a pottery, in a house where sacrificial fire is kept, on the riverside, in a mountain-cave or chasm, in a hollow tree, through a sacrificial place built near a spring, devoid of any effort, without the feeling of “Iand mine”, ever meditating on the pure Spirit, grounded in the supreme Self, extirpating all good as well as evil actions, gives up his body with complete detachment' .

column1:
tadapyutsādayāmāsa samyagjñānavivasvatā / tamasyuparate svānte teja:pujaṃ dadarśa saḥ /	‘He dispelled even that darkness by the sun of right knowledge, then he saw in the mind, cleared of darkness, a mass of light.
tallulāva sthalābjānāṃ vanaṃ bāla iva dvipaḥ //	He destroyed even that mass of light just like a young elephant destroys the forest of hibiscus .
'tejasyuparate tasya ghūrṇamānaṃ mano muneḥ / niśābjavadagānnidrāṃ tāmapyāśu lulāva saḥ //	‘When the light disappeared the mind of the sage reeled and fell asleep like the lotus shut at sunset. But he immediately shook the mind up from sleep .
'nidrāvyapagame tasya vyomasaṃvitsamudyayau /	'When awakened his mind perceived the form of space .
vyomasaṃvidi naṣṭāyāṃ mūḍhaṃ tasyābhavanmanaḥ / mohamapyeṣa manasastaṃ mamārja mahāśayaḥ / tatraiva // kāmapyavasthāmāsādya viśaśrāma manaḥ kṣaṇam //'	When this awareness of space was destroyed his mind became torpid. The magnanimous sage removed even this torpidity from his mind .'ततस्तेजस्तमोनिद्रामोहादिपरिवर्जिताम् । “Then the mind attained to that inexplicable state which is free from light, darkness, sleep, and torpor etc., and experienced peace for a while' .
ta ete vyutthānasaṃskārā nirodhahetunā yogiprayatnena pratidinaṃ pratikṣaṇaṃ cābhibhūyante; tadvirodhinaśca nirodhasaṃskārāḥ prādurbhavanti /	These mental transformations are overcome by such efforts of the yogithat are the means to control them, everyday every moment; and their opponents-controlling impressions take place.
tathā sati nirodha ekaikasminkṣaṇe cittamanugacchati / so'yamīdṛśaścittasya nirodhapariṇāmo bhavati /	When this is accomplished, the mind, in each and every moment, remains restrained . And in this manner the mind is transformed in the form of restraint i.e., restraint-transformation.
nanu 'pratikṣaṇapariṇāmino hi bhāvā ṛte citiśakteḥ '* iti nyāyena cittasya sarvadā pariṇāmapravāho vaktavyaḥ /	Objection : It must be agreed that the mind always undergoes transformations according to the rule that ‘all things, except consciousness , undergo transformations every moment' .
bāḍham /	Reply: Yes, it is indeed so.
tatra vyutthitacittasya vṛttipravāhaḥ sphuṭaḥ niruddhacittasya tu kathamityāśaṅkyottaraṃ sūtrayati sāṅkhyakaumudyām *'tata: praśāntavāhitā saṃskārāt' yosū iti /	The flow of transformations of the mind in its arisen state is evident. But how it happens in the restraint state of the mind is described in the aphorism thus : Its flow becomes steady by habit.' thus : ‘When the disciplined mind rests in the Self alone, free from longing for objects , then is one said to have attained yoga .
tāmetāṃ praśāntavāhitāṃ bhagavānvispaṣṭamudājahāra — 'yadā viniyataṃ cittamātmanyevāvatiṣṭhate / niḥspṛhaḥ sarvakāmebhyo yukta ityucyate tadā // bhagavadgītāyām // 'yathā dīpo nivātastho negate sopamā smṛtā / yogino yatacittasya yuñjato yogamātmanaḥ //	'As a lamp in a windless place does not flicker-that is the figure used for the disciplined mind of a yogipractising concentration on the Self .'यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया | “That in which the mind, restrained by the practice of concentration, rests quiescent;
yatra caivātmanātmānaṃ paśyannātmani tuṣyati //	that in which, seeing the Self through the Self, one rejoices in one's own Self .
'yaṃ labdhvā cāparaṃ lābhaṃ manyate nādhikaṃ tataḥ / yasminsthito na duḥkhena guruṇāpi vicālyate //	'That on gaining which one thinks there is no greater gain, and wherein established one is not moved even by the heaviest of sorrows – .
‘taṃ vidyād duḥkhasaṃyogaviyogaṃ yogasaṃjñitam //	‘Let that be known as yoga, which is severance from the contact of pain.
sa niścayena yoktavyo yogo'nirviṇṇacetasā //'	It is to be practised with perseverance and with an undaunted mind' .
tatraiva iti / nirodhasamādheḥ sādhanaṃ sūtrayati ‘virāmapratyayābhyāsapūrvakaḥ saṃskāraśeṣo'nyaḥ' yosū iti /	The means to nirodha samādhiconcentration of restraint is described in aphorism thus :JĪVAN-MUKIT-VIVEKA There is another samādhi which is attained by the constant practice of cessation of all mental activity, in which the citta retains only the unmanifested impressions' .
virāmo vṛttyuparamaḥ, tasya pratyaya: kāraṇaṃ vṛttyuparamārthaḥ puruṣaprayatnaḥ, tasyābhyāsa: pauna: punyena sampādanam, tatpūrvakastajjanyaḥ, anantarātītasūtre saṃprajñātasamādheruktatvāt tadapekṣayānyo'saṃprajñātaḥ samādhi /	Pratyayah means the cause of that i.e. the personal effort for the cessation of transformation; practice abhyāsah of that i.e. doing it again and again; preceded by that — tatpūrvakah — means brought about by that. As the samprajñāta samādhi-conscious concentration, has been described in the immediately preceding aphorism so by anyah the other, it is meant in relation with that asamprajñāta samādhi, i.e. the superconscious concentration.
tatra vṛttirahitasya cittasvarūpasya durlakṣyatvāt saṃskārarūpeṇa cittaṃ śiṣyate /	In that superconscious concentration the mind remains in the form of impression only, inasmuch as, being devoid of transformations, its nature cannot be described.
virāmapratyayajanyatvaṃ bhagavānvispaṣṭamāha 'saṃkalpaprabhavānkāmāṃstyaktvā sarvānaśeṣata: / manasaivendriyagrāmaṃ viniyamya samantataḥ // bhagavadgītāyām // ‘śanaiḥ śanairuparamedbuddhayā dhṛtigṛhītayā / ātmasaṃsthaṃ manaḥ kṛtvā na kiṃcidapi cintayet //	The practice of cessation as the begetter has been clearly described by the Lord thus: 2 'Renouncing entirely all the desires born of the will, drawing back the senses from every direction by the strength of mind ;228 ‘Let him little by little attain tranquillity with the intellect set in patience, and having fixed the mind on the Self he should think of nothing else .
'yato yato niścarati manaścañcalamasthiram / tatastato niyamyaitadātmanyeva vaśaṃ nayet //'	'Let him withdraw the fickle and unquiet mind from whatever causes it to wander away, and restore it to the control of the Self alone' .
tatraiva iti / kāmyamānāḥ srakcandanavanitāputramitragṛhakṣetrādayo mokṣaśāstrakuśala vivekijanaprasiddhairbahubhirdoṣairupetā apyanādyavidyāvaśāt tāndoṣānācchādya teṣu viṣayeṣu samyaktvaṃ manaḥ kalpayati /	Although desired things such as flower garland, sandalwood paste, women, children, friends, houses, lands and the like are full of many evils which are well-known to the discriminating people who are well versed in the discipline of liberation, yet the mind, under the influence of beginningless ignorance, covers up all those evils and imagines them to be all right.
tasmācca saṃkalpādidaṃ me syādityevaṃrūpāḥ kāmāḥ prabhavanti /	Out of such imagination desires are born in the form as 'Let this be mine'.
tathā ca smaryate 'saṃkalpamūla: kāmo vai yajñāḥ saṃkalpasaṃbhavāḥ /'	The smrti also has it thus : 'Desire is truly rooted in imagination , even the sacrifices are born of imagination ' .
tatra vivekena viṣayadoṣeṣu sākṣātkṛteṣu śunā vānte pāyasa iva kāmāstyajyante /	When through discrimination the evils in the objects of enjoyment are realized, desires are given up, even as the porridge vomited by a dog is shunned.
sakvandanādiṣviva brahmalokādiṣvaṇimādyaṣṭaiśvaryeṣu ca kāmāstyājyā ityabhipretya sarvānityuktam/ māsopavāsavratinā tasminmāse'nne tyakte'pi kāmaḥ punaḥ punarudeti; tadvanmā bhūdityaśeṣata ityuktam /	The word 'entire'sarvān ~ has been used to imply that the desires for the world of Brahma etc., and for the eight occult powers such as to become atomized etc., are also to be given up like the desires for garland etc. As when a man has taken a vow to fast in a particular month and in observance of that although he gives up eating in that month yet the desire for food arises again and again, to obviate such a state of affair the word 'entirely' asesatah , without reserve or exception, has been used.
kāmatyāge manaḥpūrvakapravṛttyabhāve'pi cakṣurādīnāṃ rūpādiṣu yā svabhāvasiddhā pravṛttiḥ sāpi prayatnayuktena manasaiva niyantavyā / devatādarśanādiṣvapyananusaraṇāya samantata ityuktam / bhūmikājayakrameṇoparamasya vivakṣitatvācchanaiḥ śanairityuktam /	Desires having been given up, although there is no intentional activity of the sense-organs yet the normal functioning of the eye etc. of perceiving form etc. is to be controlled with an enterprising mind .From every direction-samantatah has been used to mean that no indulgence is to be given even to the desire of god-vision etc. The use of ‘little by little'-sanaih sanaih is meant for gaining tranquillity by stages.
tāśca bhūmikāścatasraḥ kaṭhavallīṣu śrūyante 'yacchedvāṅmanasī prājñastadyacchejjñāna ātmani /	There are four of these stages as described in the Kathopanisad thus : “The wise man should merge his speech in his mind, and his mind in his intellect.
jñānamātmani mahati niyacchettadyacchecchānta ātmani //	He should merge his intellect in the Cosmic Mind, and the Cosmic Mind in the Tranquil Self' .
vāgvyāpāro dvividhaḥ – laukiko vaidikaśca /	The organ of speech has twofold function: ordinary speech and vaidika speech.
jalpādirūpo laukika:, japādirūpo vaidikaḥ /	The ordinary is in the form of usual conversation etc. and the vedic is in the form of muttering of passages etc. from the scriptures.
tatra laukikasya bahuvikṣepakaratvād vyutthānakāle'pi yogī taṃ parityajet /	Of them the ordinary speech causes distraction in various ways, therefore the yogi should eschew it even when he is risen from concentration.
ata eva smaryate 'maunaṃ yogāsanaṃ yogastitikṣaikāntaśīlatā / niḥspṛhatvaṃ samatvaṃ ca saptaitānyekadaṇḍinaḥ //' nārada pari upa iti / japādikaṃ nirodhasamādhau parityajet /	Hence the smrti has it thus : 'Silence, yogic posture, , practice of meditation, fortitude, living in solitude, desirelessness and equableness-these seven are for the single-staff-carrying monk' . In the concentration of restraint muttering etc. should be given up.
seyaṃ vāgbhūmiḥ prathamā /	So this is the first stage the speech-stage.
tāṃ bhūmiṃ prayatnamātreṇa katipayairdinairmāsairvatsarairvā dṛḍhaṃ vijitya paścādvitīyāyāṃ manobhūmau prayateta; anyathā bahubhūmikāprāsādavatprathamabhūmipātenaivoparitanayogabhūmayaḥ sarvā vinaśyeyuḥ/	This stage should be brought under firm control first by effort alone in a matter of days or months or years, afterwards should attempt the second stage the mental plane. Otherwise , failure to conquer the first stage will lead to the collapse of all the yogic stages, even as the many-storeyed house collapses at the breakdown of the first storey.
yadyapi cakṣurādayo niroddhavyāḥ, tathāpi teṣāṃ vāgbhūmau manobhūmau vāntarbhāvo draṣṭavyaḥ /	Though the eye etc. are also to be controlled, but they should be understood to have been included in the speech-stage or mind-stage.
nanu vācaṃ manasi niyacchedityanupapannam; na hīndriyasyendriyāntare praveśo'sti /	Objection: It has been said 'should merge his speech in his mind' and which cannot be justified since there is no entry of one organ into another.
praveśasyāvivakṣitatvāt /	16JIVAN-MUKTI-VIVEKA fafa-fth &fa:Reply: It is not so, because entering is not meant here.
nānāvikṣepakāriṇorvāṅmanasayormadhye prathamato vāgvyāpāraniyamanena manovyāpāramātrapariśeṣa iha vivakṣitaḥ /	What is meant here is this speech and mind, both are the cause of various distractions; of them by controlling the function of speech first, the functions of the mind only remains to be controlled.
gomahiṣāśvādīnāmiva vāniyame svābhāvike saṃpanne tato jñānātmani mano niyacchet /	When the control of speech becomes as natural as that of cows, buffaloes, horses, and the like, then the mind should be merged in the knowing-self.
ātmā trividhaḥ, jñānātmā mahātmā śāntātmā ceti /	The Self is of three kinds: the knowing-Self, the great Self, and the Tranquil Self.
jānātyatra sthita sthita ātmeti jñātṛtvopādhirahaṃkāro'tra jñānaśabdena vivakṣitaḥ, karaṇasya manaso niyamyatvena pṛthagupāttatvāt /	The Self present as an agent in the act of knowing i.e. the egoism attributed as knower is meant here by the words 'the knowing Self'; since the mind, which is the instrument of knowledge, is to be controlled, that is why it is being mentioned separately.
ahaṃkāro dvividhaḥ viśeṣarūpa: sāmānyarūpaśceti /	Egoism is of two kinds: individual and universal.
‘ayamahametasya putra' ityevaṃ vyaktamabhimanyamāno viśeṣarūpaḥ/	Thus 'Here I am son of so and so'such manifest particular egoism belongs to the individual form of egoism.
‘asmi’ ityetāvanmātramabhimanyamānaḥ sāmānyarūpaḥ sa ca sarvavyaktiṣu vyāptatvātmahānityucyate /	And 'I am'-only this much thinking belongs to the universal form of egoism. Since this universal variety exists in every individual, it is called greatmahän.
tābhyāmahaṃkārābhyāṃ dvābhyāmupahitau dvāvātmānau /	The two selves are thus attributed to by the two egoisms .
nirupādhikaḥ śāntātmā /	Attributeless is the Tranquil Self.
tadetatsarvamantarbahirbhāvena vartate /	They all happen to be in an inner and outer relation.
śānta ātmā sarvāntaraścidekarasaḥ/ tasminnāśritaṃ jaḍaśaktirūpamavyaktaṃ mūlaprakṛtiḥ /	The innermost is the Tranquil Self which is pure knowledge, wherein exists, in the form of physical power, the unmanifest-avyakta, primordial nature-mūla-prakrti, the cause.
sā ca prathamaṃ sāmānyāhaṃkārarūpeṇa mahattattvanāmnā vyaktībhavati /	This manifests itself at first in the form of universal egoism and is called the greatprinciple-mahat-tattva .
tato bahirviśeṣāhaṃkārarūpeṇa, tato bahirmanorūpeṇa tato bahirvāgādīndriyarūpeṇa / tadetadabhipretyottarottaramāntaratvaṃ 'indriyebhyaḥ parā hyarthā arthebhyaśca paraṃ manaḥ /	Outer to that it manifests in the form of individual egoism and again outer to this in the form of the mind and farther out to this in the form of the organs, such as of speech etc. With all this in view the śruti describes their gradual inwardness one by one thus : 'Beyond the senses are the objects; beyond the objects is the mind;
manasastu parā buddhirbuddherātmā mahānparaḥ //	beyond the mind, the intellect; beyond the intellect, the Great atman;
mahata: paramavyaktamavyaktāt puruṣaḥ paraḥ /	beyond the Great atman, the Unmanifest; beyond the Unmanifest, the Puruşa.
puruṣānna paraṃ kiṃcitsā kāṣṭhā sā parā gatiḥ //'	Beyond the Purusa there is nothing this is the end, the Supreme Goal' .
evaṃ satyatra nānāvidhasaṃkalpavikalpasādhanaṃ karaṇarūpaṃ mano'haṃkartari niyacchet / manovyāpārānparityajyāhaṃkāramātraṃ śeṣayet /	Therefore, the mind which produces a variety of thoughts, in the form of the instrument of deliberation, should be merged in the egoity. That means giving up mental activities retain the egoity — the I-consciousness only.
na caitadaśakyamiti vācyam, 'tasyāhaṃ nigrahaṃ manye vāyoriva suduṣkaram //' bhagavadgītāyām iti vadantamarjunaṃ prati bhagavatottarābhidhānāt ‘asaṃśayaṃ mahābāho mano durnigrahaṃ calam /	It cannot be said that this is not possible since in reply to Arjuna's statement — To control it is as hard, it seems to me, as to control the wind' , the Lord said thus : ‘Doubtless, O mighty Arjuna, the mind is restless and hard to control;
abhyāsena tu kaunteya vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate //asaṃyatātmanā yogo duṣprāpa iti me matiḥ /	but by practice and by detachment, O son of Kunti, it can be restrained. Yoga is hard to attain, I think, by a man who cannot control himself;
vaśyātmanā tu yatatā śakyo'vāptumupāyataḥ //' bhagavadgītāyām , iti /	but it can be attained by him who has controlled himself and who strives by right means' .
abhyāsavairāgye patañjalisūtrodāharaṇena vyākhyāsyete /	Practice and detachment will be explained later quoting Patañjali's aphorisms.
pūrvapūrvabhūmidāḍharcarahi to'saṃyatātmā/ tatsahito vaśyātmā /	Who has no ascendency over the previous stages is meantby withoutself-control—asamyatatmā, and who has it is called the self-controlled— vaśyātmā.
upāyata: prāptiṃ gauḍapādācāryā: sadṛṣṭāntamāhuḥ 'utseka udadheryadvatkuśāgreṇaikabindunā / manaso nigrahastadvadbhavedaparikhedataḥ //' māṇḍūkyakārikāyām iti /	Acārya Gaudapāda has illustrated how by right means yoga is attained thus : ‘The mind is to be brought under control by undepressed effort : it is like emptying the ocean drop by drop, with the help of a blade of kusa grass' .
'bahubhirna viroddhavyamekenāpi balīyasā / sa parābhavamāpnoti samudra iva ṭiṭṭibhāt //'	'Although the mind is very powerful yet it cannot hold on alone against the many efforts of the yogi and is defeated even as the ocean was defeated by the tittibha bird' .
atra saṃpradāyavida ākhyāyikāmācakṣate–'kasyacitkila pakṣiṇo'ṇḍāni tīrasthānyudadhirutsekenāpajahāra /	Vedantic tradition has a story in this context thus : The eggs of some bird which were laid on the shore were carried away by the ocean by flowing tide.
taṃ ca samudraṃ śoṣayāmīti pravṛttaḥ sa ca pakṣī svamukhāgreṇaikaikaṃ jalabinduṃ bahiḥ prakṣipati sma /	Determined to retrieve the eggs by drying up the ocean, it started throwing out water drop by drop by its beak.
tadā bahubhiḥ pakṣibhirbandhu vargairvāryamāṇo'pyanuparataḥ pratyuta tānapi sahakāriṇo vavre /	Although discouraged by its friends and many other birds it did not desist rather requested them to assist.
tāṃśca patanotpatanābhyāṃ bahudhā kliśyataḥ sarvānavalokya kṛpālurnārado garuḍaṃ samīpe preṣayāmāsa /	The compassionate Nārada, seeing them suffer in various ways, flying in and out of the ocean, was moved and sent Garuda there.
tato garuḍapakṣavātena śuṣyansamudro bhītastānyaṇḍānyānīya pakṣiṇe dadau' / , evamakhedena manonirodhe paramadharme pravartamānaṃ yoginamīśvaro'nugṛhṇāti /	Then the frightened ocean, which started to dry up by the wind produced by the fluttering of the wings of Garuda, returned those eggs.' Controlling the mind is the highest religious deed and the Lord helps the yogi in the same manner, who is engaged in this with undepressed effort.
akhedaśca madhye madhye tadanukūlavyāpāramiśraṇena saṃpadyate, yathaudanaṃ bhuñjānastattadgrāsāntare coṣyalehyādīnāsvādayati tadvat /	Weariless effort takes place by mixing other favourable activities with it from time to time; it is just like tasting other courses while eating rice such as soup, curd, etc. between the morsels.
idamevābhipretya vasiṣṭha āha 'cittasya bhogai bhāgau śāstreṇaikaṃ prapūrayet / guruśuśrūṣayā bhāgamavyutpannasya satkrame // laghuyogavāsiṣṭhe //	With this in view Vasistha said thus : “The beginner should follow the right course of yoga thus: he should fill two parts of his mind with objects of enjoyment, one part by the study of scriptures, and one part by attending on his preceptor .
'vyutpattimanuyātasya pūrayeccetaso'nvaham / dvau bhāgau śāstravairāgyairdvī dhyānagurupūjayā //' tatraiva iti / bhogaśabdenātra jīvanaheturbhikṣāṭanādivyāpāro varṇāśramocitavyāpāraścocyate /	The word bhoga objects of enjoyment means here such acts as to go for begging food to subsist on and the like, and such activities as required according to the caste and stage of life. He should practise yoga according to his ability for one ghatikā or one muhurta i.e. twenty-four minutes or fo rty-eight minutes;
ghaṭikāmātraṃ muhūrtaṃ vā yathāśakti yogamabhyasya tato muhūrtaṃ śāstraśravaṇena paricaryayā vā gurūnanugamya muhūrtaṃ svadehamanusṛtya muhūrtaṃ yogaśāstraṃ paryālocya punarmuhūrtaṃ yogamabhyasyet /	then a muhurta he should spend with his teacher in studying scripture and also in serving him and the next muhūrta in meeting the needs of his own body, then the next muhurta in the study of the science of yoga, and then again he should practise yoga.
evaṃ yogaprādhānyena vyāpārāntarāṇi melayaṃstāni drāgabhyasya śayanakāle taddinagatān yogamuhūrtān gaṇayet /	Thus, laying greater emphasis on yoga he should mingle all other activities with it and should finish them quickly, then retiring to bed he should count the muhurtas devoted to yoga.
tataḥ paredhurvā parapakṣe vā paramāse vā yogamuhūrtān vardhayet /	Then he should increase the muhurtas of yoga next day or in the next fortnight or in the next month.
tathā caikaikasminmuhūrta ekaikakṣaṇayoge'pi saṃvatsaramātreṇa bhūyānyogakālo bhavati /	In this manner by adding even a moment to the yoga-muhurta the time of yoga will become greatly increased in just a year.
na caivaṃ yaugaikaśaraṇatve vyāpārāntarāṇi lupyeranniti śaṅkanīyam, luptetarakṛtsnavyāpārasyaiva yoge'dhikārāt / ata eva vidvatsaṃnyāso'pekṣyate /	It should not be doubted that by paying exclusive attention to yoga other activities would be left uncared for, for, only he becomes fit for the practice of yoga who has left all other activities, which is why vidvatsannyāsa—the renunciation of the knower — is required.
tasmāttadekaniṣṭhaḥ pumānadhyetṛvaṇigādivatkrameṇa yogārūḍho bhavati /	Hence the man who devotes himself exclusively attains to yoga gradually just like a student or a trader.
, yathādhyetā māṇavakaḥ māṇavakaḥ pādāṃśaṃ pādamardharcamṛcamṛgvayaṃ varga ca krameṇa paṭhandaśadvādaśavarṣairadhyāpako bhavati, yathā ca vāṇijyaṃ kurvanneka niṣkadviniṣkādikrameṇa lakṣapatiḥ koṭipatirvā bhavati tathā tābhyāṃ vaṇigadhyetṛbhyāṃ sahaivopakramya matsaragrasta iva yuñjānastāvatā kālena kuto na yogamārohet ? tasmātpunaḥ punaḥ prāpyamāṇānsaṃkalpavikalpānuddālakavat pauruṣaprayatnena parityajyāhaṃkartari jñānātmani mano niyacchet /	As a student studying the Vedas gradually learns a part of a quarter of a rk first, then a quarter, then a half, then a full rk, then two rks, and then a section, and in this way by ten or twelve years becomes himself a teacher, or as one dealing in merchandise makes profit by one rupee, then two rupees and in this way becomes a millionaire; even so beginning with themthe student and the trader — and with a spirit of competition practising yoga, why should he not attain yoga in that extent of time? column2: If Yoga is practised for a long time but with interruptions then the impressions arising from yoga will be subdued by the impressions born of interruptions during arousal from yoga in the same manner as the author of KhandanaKhandakhādya has described— 'Like the reading of a man of forgetful nature, while learns the following word forgets the foregoing one, i.e. while advancing if previous gains are lost then on what should be his stay' .

column1: tasmānnirantaramāsevitavyaḥ /
column2: Therefore, yoga is to be practised without interruptions.

column2: If practised without proper care it will be in the same manner as Vasistha said thus : ‘As a man, being absent-minded, although hears something yet is not the agent of hearing, even so, although doing something yet does not do whose mind is devoid of desires' .

column2: The firmly groundedness of concentration practised through threefold-long, constant, and careful—exercise, means remaining not moved by the desire of enjoyment or the desire of pain.

column2: The same has been described by the Lord thus : 'That on gaining which one thinks there is no greater gain, and wherein established one is not moved even by the heaviest of sorrow' .अपरलाभस्यानाधिक्यं कचवृत्तान्तेन वसिष्ठ उदाजहार Other gain whatever is not greater than the gain of this state has been described by Vasistha in the episode of Kaca thus : 'Once upon a time, Kaca, arisen from concentration in a solitary spot, very pleased in mind, said stammeringly thus : 'What shall I do, where shall I go, what shall I take and what shall I give ? since the universe is filled with the Self, like the great cyclical cataclysm .

column2:
Inside and outside the body, below and above and on all sides, here and there, the Self is everywhere ;
ita ātmā tathehātmā nāstyanātmamayaṃ kvacit // na tadasti na yatrāhaṃ na tadasti na yanmayi /	and there is nothing nowhere which is not-Self . “There is nothing wherein I am not, and there is nothing that is not in me ;
kimanyadabhivāñchāmi sarvaṃ saṃvinmayaṃ tatam // laghuyogavāsiṣṭhe /	what else is there that I may desire, when everything around is pervaded by the supreme consciousness alone' .
'sphārabrahmāmalāmbhodhe: phenāḥ sarve kulācalā: /	“The great mountain ranges of the world are merely the bubbles of the all-pervading pure ocean of Brahman;
cidādityamahātejomṛgatṛṣṇā jagacchriyaḥ //' , tatraiva iti /	and in all its manifestations this world is but a mirage appearing in the great light of the sun of consciousness' .
guruduḥkhenāpyavicālyatvaṃ śikhidhvajasya vatsaratrayasamādhivṛttāntenodājahāra 'nirvikalpasamādhisthaṃ tatrāpaśyanmahīpatim / rājānaṃ tāvadetasmāt bodhayāmi parātpadāt // iti saṃcintya cūḍālā siṃhanādaṃ cakāra sā / bhūyo bhūyaḥ prabhoragre vanecarabhayapradam //	Remaining unmoved even by great guruduhkhenāpyavicālyatvam—has been described in the episode of the three year concentration of Sikhidhvaja thus : sorrow'Cūdālā, the queen of Sikhidhvaja, found there the lord of the earth immersed in superconscious concentration, and having resolved then to wake the king up from that supreme state, she roared like a lion in front of the lord repeatedly frightening the forest-dwellers' .
cālita: pātito'pyeṣa tadā no bubudhe budhaḥ //iti / laghuyogavāsiṣṭhe // , prahlādavṛttāntenāpyetadevodājahāra ' iti saṃcintayantreva prahlādaḥ paravīrahā / nirvikalpaparānandasamādhiṃ samupāyayau //tatraiva /	पञ्च वर्षसहस्राणि पीनाङ्गोऽतिष्ठदेकदृक् ॥ Vasistha described the same thing in the episode of Prahlada thus : ‘While thinking thus, Prahlāda, the destroyer of brave enemies, attained to the supremely blissful state of superconscious concentration .
nirvikalpasamādhisthaścitrārpita ivābabhau / mahātman saṃprabudhyasvetyevaṃ viṣṇurudāharat / pāñcajanyaṃ pradadhmau ca dhvanayan kakubhāṃ gaṇam //tatraiva mahatā tena śabdena vaiṣṇavaprāṇajanmanā /	‘In that state of superconscious concentration he remai ned motionless and looked, as it were, like a picture, upright, gazing on the unity, for five thousand years . By that great sound born of the vital breath of the Lord Visnu, the king of the demons slowly awoke' .
tatraiva iti / evaṃ vītahavyādīnāmapi samādhirudāharaṇīyaḥ /	Thus the concentration of Vitahavya and the like may also be cited.
vairāgyaṃ dvividham, aparaṃ paraṃ ceti /	Non-attachment —vairāgyam — is of two kinds : lower and higher.
yatamānavyatirekaikendriyavaśīkārabhedairaparaṃ caturvidham /	The lower variety of non-attachment again has four stages of development namely;
tatrādyaṃ trayamarthātsūtra yansākṣāccaturthaṃ sūtrayati 'dṛṣṭānuśravikaviṣayavitṛṣṇasya vaśīkārasaṃjñā vairāgyam' yogasūtreṣu iti /	While defining the fourth — subjugation, the first three have been implied in the aphorism thus : “That effect which comes to those who have given up their thirst after objects, either seen or heard, andJĪVAN-MUKTI VIVEKA which wills to control the objects, is non-attachment' .
srakcandanavanitāputramitrakṣetradhanādayo dṛṣṭāḥ /	Garlands, sandalwood, women, sons, friends, land, riches, and the like are the objects seen ;
vedoktāḥ svargādaya ānuśravikāḥ /	and heaven and the like are the objects heard.
tatrobhayatra satyāmapi tṛṣṇāyāṃ vivekatāratamyena yatamānādivairāgyatrayaṃ bhavati /	Inspite of the thirst being present after the objects of both varieties, the three stages — endeavour etc. of non-attachment are ascertained by the degree of discrimination.
asmiñjagati kiṃ sāraṃ kimasāramiti guruśāstrābhyāṃ jñāsyāmītyudyogo yatamānatvam , svacitte pūrvaṃ vidyamānānāṃ doṣāṇāṃ madhye'bhyasyamānena vivekenaitāvantaḥ pakvā etāvanto'vaśiṣṭā iti vivecanaṃ vyatirekaḥ , dṛṣṭānuśravikaviṣayapravṛtterduḥkhātmatvabodhena tāṃ pravṛttiṃ parityajya manasaścautsukyamātreṇa vitṛṣṇāvasthānamekendriyatvam , vitṛṣṇatvaṃ vaśīkāra: , tadidamaparaṃ vairāgyamaṣṭāṅgayogapravartakatvena saṃprajñātasyāntaram, asaṃprajñātasya tu bahiraṅgam/	Such attempts as — I shall learn from teachers and scriptures what in this world is of worth and what is worthless'—is the stage of endeavour. The separating, out of the defects that were present in the mind which have ripened by the exercise of discrimination from those that are yet to ripen, is the stage of analysis. When enjoying objects is given up with the understanding that all such enjoyments of objects, whether seen or heard, are miserable, only the longing remains in the mind; such thirstless state is the uni-sense stage of non-attachment.270 Complete non-attachment is named the stage of subjugation. Therefore, the lower kind of non-attachment--aparam vairāgyam-being the promoter of eight-limbed yoga, forms the internal means to the conscious variety of concentration, but it is external to superconscious concentration.
tatrāntaraṅgaṃ paraṃ vairāgyaṃ sūtrayati 'tatparaṃ puruṣakhyāterguṇavaitṛṣṇyam' iti /	The higher non-attachment-param vairāgyam— which is internal to superconscious concentration is being formulated thus : “That is extreme non-attachment which gives up even the qualities, and comes from the knowledge of the Purusa .
saṃprajñātasamādhipāṭavena guṇatrayātmakātpradhānādviraktasya puruṣasya khyātiḥ sākṣātkāra utpadyate /	Through the intense practice of conscious concentration the realization of the Purusathe Self, which is perfectly non-attached to the pradhāna comprising the three modes, takes place;
tasmācca sākṣātkārādaśeṣaguṇatrayavyavahāre yadvaitṛṣṇyaṃ tatparaṃ vairāgyam / tasya tāratamyena samādheḥ śīghratvatāratamyaṃ sūtrayati — 'tīvrasaṃvegānāmāsannaḥ' yogasūtreṣu samādhilābhaḥ iti /	and from that realization arises the desirelessness to all manifestations of the three modes, which is called extreme non-attachment. Patañjali describes the varying degrees of rapidity in the attainment of concentration according to the varying degrees of non-attachment in the aphorism thus : ‘Success is speedy for the extremely energetic' .
tadbhedādyoginastrividhāḥ mṛdusaṃvegā madhyasaṃvegāstī vrasaṃvegāśceti /	According to the degrees of non-attachment the yogis are of three classes: of weak non-attachment, of moderate non-attachment and of intense non-attachment.
āsanno'lpenaiva kālena samādhirlabhyata ityarthaḥ /	Speedy āsannah — means the attainment of concentration just in a short time.
tīvrasaṃvegeṣveva samādhitāratamyaṃ sūtrayati 'mṛdumadhyādhimātratvāttato'pi viśeṣa : ' yogasūtreṣu iti /	Varying degrees of concentration are due to the varying degrees of even the intense non-attachment, which is being formulated thus : ‘The success of the yogis differs according as the means they adopt are mild, medium or intense' .
mṛdutīvro madhyatīvro'dhimātratīvra iti /	Thus mildly intense, moderately intense, and extremely intense .
teṣvapyuttarottarasya tvarayā siddhirdraṣṭavyā /	Among them it is to be understood that the latter gains concentration quicker than the former.
uttamottamā janakaprahlādādayo'dhimātratīvrāḥ, muhūrtamātravicāreṇa dṛḍhasamādhilābhāt /	The best among the best are Janaka, Prahlāda and the like who belong to the class of yogis with extremely intense non-attachment, for they could attain firm concentration by reflection for a moment only.
adhamādhamā uddālakādayo mṛdusaṃvegāḥ, ciraprayāsena tallābhāt /	Uddālaka and others are the worst of the worst class possessing weak non-attachment, for they attained concentration after prolonged endeavour.
evamanye'pi yathāyogamunneyāḥ /	Other yogis also can be classified accordingly in this manner.
tadevamadhimātratīvrasya dṛr̤habhūmāvasaṃprajñātasamādhau labdhe sati punarvyutthātumaśaktaṃ sanmano naśyati/	Therefore, the mind of the yogi, possessed of extremely intense non-attachment, being unable to rise from the firmly grounded superconscious concentration, becomes extinct.
manonāśena ca vāsanākṣaye rakṣite sati jīvanmuktiḥ supratiṣṭhitā bhavati /	By the extinction of the mind desirelessness is maintained and jivanmukti becomes firmly established.
na ca manonāśena videhamuktireva na tu jīvanmuktiriti śaṅkanīyam, praśnottarābhyāṃ tannirṇayāt / 'vivekābhyudayāccittasvarūpe'ntarhite mune / maitryādayo guṇāḥ kutra jāyante yogināṃ vada // laghuyogavāsiṣṭhe //	It cannot be maintained that dissolution of the mind leads to disembodied liberation— videhamukti, not to jivanmukti, inasmuch as the following questions and answers refute that theory thus : The Lord Rama: 'O sage, tell me where the friendship and the like virtues are born, when the minds of the yogis disappear with its forms with the rise of discrimination ? .
'dvividhaścittanāśo'sti sarūpo'rūpa eva ca /	वसिष्ठ Vasistha 'Dissolution of the mind is of two kinds: with form and without form.
jīvanmuktau sarūpa: syādarūpo'dehamuktigaḥ // tatraiva /	In jivanmukti the dissolution is with form and is without form in videhamukti .
śrīrāma: 'prākṛtaṃ guṇasaṃbhāraṃ mameti bahu manyate /	'The mind variously thinks the qualities of nature— prakrti — as mine;
sukhaduḥkhādyavaṣṭabhya vidyamānaṃ mano viduḥ // tatraiva //	so the learned understand that being possessed with pleasure, pain and the like is the existence of the mind .
'cetasaḥ kathitā sattā mayā raghukulodvaha /	‘The existence of mind, O descendant of the family of Raghu , has been explained by me.
asya nāśamidānīṃ tvaṃ śṛṇu praśnavidāṃ vara //	Now you hear, O best of the enquirers, the dissolution of it .
'sukhaduḥkhadaśā dhīraṃ sāmyānna proddharanti yam / niḥśvāsā iva śailendraṃ tasya cittaṃ mṛtaṃ viduḥ //	“The learned know that the mind of the wise is dead whom the state of pleasure or pain cannot move from its sameness even as the Himalaya cannot be moved by the flow of breath .
'āpatkārpaṇyamutsāho mado māndyaṃ mahotsavaḥ / yaṃ nayanti na vairūpyaṃ tasya naṣṭaṃ mano viduḥ // tatraiva // 'cittamāśānidhānaṃ hi yadā naśyati rāghava / maitryādibhirguṇairyuktaṃ tadā sattvamudetyalam /	‘His mind is known to be dissolved on whom no change can be brought about by adversity, joy, pitiful circumstances, pride, disease, or a great festival .274 'When the mind, the store-house of hopes, is dissolved, O Rāghava, the ascendency of sattva comprising all the qualities, such as friendship and the like, takes place .
‘bhūyojanmavinirmuktaṃ jīvanmuktasya tanmanaḥ / sarūpo'sau manonāśo jīvanmuktasya vidyate //	“That mind of the jivanmukta which is freed from rebirth, is the dissolved mind with form, and belongs to the jivanmukta .
'arūpastu manonāśo yo mayokto raghūdvaha / videhamuktāvevāsau vidyate niṣkalātmakaḥ //	'O descendant of the Raghus, the dissolution of the mind without form, which has been described by me, happens in the case of videhamukti only wherein remains no trace of the mind .
'samagrāgūyaguṇādhāramapi sattvaṃ pralīyate / videhamuktāvamale pade paramapāvane // tatraiva // ‘saṃśāntaduḥkhamajaḍātmakamekarūpa mānandamantharamapetarajastamo yat / ākāśakośatanavo'tanavo mahānta stasminpade galitacittalavā vasanti //'	“The intellect as pure sattva guna, in spite of its being the receptacle of all the good qualities, dissolves in that pure, supreme, holy state called videhamukti . 'The great souls, without body, having the ākāśa, as though, as their bodies, remain in that state which is devoid of rajas and tamas, ever pure knowledge, completely free from pain and the stronghold of bliss, wherein the apparent mindstuff has disappeared .
'jīvanmuktā na muhyanti sukhaduḥkharasasthitau / prākṛtenārthakāreṇa kiṃcitkurvanti vā na vā /'	“The jivanmuktas are never deluded whether in a pleasurable state or in a painful state, while doing or not doing the usual purposeful acts' .
tatraiva / tasmātsarūpo manonāśo jīvanmuktisādhanamiti sthitam //	Therefore, it is established that the dissolution of the mind with form is the means to jivanmukti.
iti śrīmadvidyāraṇyapraṇīte jīvanmuktiviveke manonāśanirūpaṇaṃ nāma tṛtīyaṃ prakaraṇam //	End of the third chapter on the dissolution of the mind.चतुर्थं स्वरूपसिद्धिप्रयोजनप्रकरणम् । FOURTH CHAPTER The purpose that the accomplishment of Jivanmukti serves.
keyaṃ jīvanmuktiḥ, kiṃ vā tatra pramāṇam, kathaṃ vā tatsiddhiḥ, ityetasya praśnatrayasyottaraṃ nirūpitam /	What is Jivanmukti? What are the proofs of it ? And how is it accomplished ? These three questions have been answered in the foregoing chapters.
siddhūyā vā kiṃ prayojanamityasya caturthapraśnasyottaramidānīmabhidhīyate jñānarakṣātapovisaṃvādābhāvaduḥkhanāśasukhāvirbhāvāḥ santi pañca prayojanāni /	Now the answer to the fourth question— what purpose does the accomplishment of Jivanmukti serve ?' – is being given. The purpose is five-fold: protection of knowledge; practice of religious austerity; absence of disagreement; disappearance of sorrow;
nanu pramāṇotpannasya tattvajñānasya ko nāma bādhaprasaṅgo yena rakṣā apekṣyata iti ceducyate – cittaviśrāntyabhāve saṃśayaviparyayau prasajyeyātām /	It may be asked — what is the necessity of protecting knowledge ? The question of sublation does not arise inasmuch as the knowledge of Reality has been obtained through proper evidence. The answer is this — in the absence of tranquillity of the mind doubt and error may creep in;
tathā hi — tattvavido rāghavasya viśrānteḥ pūrvaṃ saṃśayaṃ viśvāmitra udājahāra 'na rāghava tavāstyanyajjñeyaṃ jñānavatāṃ vara / svayaiva sūkṣmayā buddhyā sarvaṃ vijñātavānasi //	for instance, ViśvāmitraJĪVAN-MUKTI VIVEKA describes the doubt in the mind of Rāghava, the knower of truth, before it attained calmness thus : ‘O Rāghava, there remains nothing else to be known by you, O the best among the wise, you have, with your own subtle intellect, known everything .
bhagavadvyāsaputrasya śukasyeva matistava / viśrāntimātramevātra jñātajñeyāpyapekṣate //'	‘Like Suka, the son of his holiness Vyāsa, your intellect, although has known what was to be known, requires here rest' .
śukastu svayamevādau tattvaṃ viditvā tatra saṃśayānaḥ pitaraṃ pṛṣṭvā pitrāpi tathaivānuśiṣṭastatrāpi saṃśayāno janakamupasadya tenāpi tathaivānuśiṣṭastaṃ pratyevamuvāca, śrīśukaḥ – 'svayameva mayā pūrvametajjñātaṃ vivekata: / etadeva hi pṛṣṭena pitrā me samudāhṛtam //	Suka first realized truth himself but entertained doubt in it; he asked his fatherVyāsa— who instructed him the same thing but still he had doubt in it, so, went to Janaka and was instructed in the same manner. Then he said to Janaka thus : Suka: “Through discrimination I came to know this myself before, and this alone my father, when asked, properly illustrated . ‘You have also said the same thing, O the best among the learned ;
eṣa eva ca vākyārthaḥ śāstreṣu paridṛśyate //	and this alone is the meaning of the sentence that is found in the scriptures .
yathāyaṃ svavikalpotthaḥ svavikalpaparikṣayāt / kṣīyate dagdhasaṃsāro niḥsāra iti niścayaḥ // tatkimetanmahābāho satyaṃ brūhi mamācalam / tvatto viśrāntimāpnomi cetasā bhrāmitaṃ jagat //	‘O mighty one, is this real ? Tell me, then, that it may become steady since my mind, owing to doubt, makes me also restless, so that I may obtain tranquillity इति ॥ Janaka: 'O sage, there is no other conviction of any kind superior to that which you have realized yourself and then heard from your teacher again .
janaka: 'nātaḥ parataraḥ kaścinniścayo'styaparo mune /	'In this world there is only one, undivided Puruṣa, who is pure intelligence, and none else.
svasaṃkalpavaśābaddho niḥsaṃkalpastu mucyate //	He has become bound by his own mentations and shall be freed with the subsidence of the same .
mune tvayā sphuṭaṃ jñātaṃ jñeyaṃ svasya mahātmanaḥ / bhogebhyo viratirjātā dṛśyādvā sakalādiha //	'O sage, you have known clearly what was to be known and in your own great self the non-attachment to enjoyments is born or to all this whatever is perceivable in this world .
prāptaṃ prāptavyamakhilaṃ bhavatā pūrṇacetasā / na dṛśye yatase brahman muktastvaṃ bhrāntimutsṛja //	‘O Brahman, everything you have got that was to be got, your mind being full you will not devote to perceivable things; you are free, give up delusion .
vītaśokabhayāyāso nirīhaśchinnasaṃśayaḥ / jagāma śikharaṃ mero: samādhyarthamaninditam //	'Freed from sorrow, fear, and endeavour, devoid of effort, and doubts resolved, Sukawent to the peak of mount Meru favourable for the practice of concentration .
tatra varṣasahasrāṇi nirvikalpasamādhinā / daśa sthitvā śaśāmāsāvātmanyasnehadīpavat //	'For ten thousand years he remained in superconscious concentration there, and then was merged in the Self, as a lamp is extinguished without oil' .
tasmādvidite'pi tattve viśrāntirahitasya śukarāghavayoriva saṃśaya utpadyate /	Therefore, doubt arises in him who is without tranquillity even though he has known the truth like Rāghava and Suka.
sa cājñānamiva mokṣasya pratibandhakaḥ / ata eva bhagavatoktam 'ajñaścāśraddadhānaśca saṃśayātmā vinaśyati /	And doubt is an obstacle to liberation like ignorance which is why the Lord said thus : ‘The man who is ignorant, and has no faith, and who is of a doubting nature, perishes.
nāyaṃ loko'sti na paro na sukhaṃ saṃśayātmanaḥ //'	Not this world, nor the world beyond, nor happiness is for the doubting soul' .
ajñānaviparyayau mokṣamātravirodhinau; saṃśayastu bhogamokṣayorubhayorapi virodhī, tasya parasparaviruddhakoṭi dvayāvalambitvāt / yadā saṃsārasukhāya pravṛttistadā mokṣamārge buddhistāṃ niruṇaddhi /	परमपुरुषार्थभ्रंशो मा भूदिति कृपया गुरुः पुनरागत्य बोधयामास । तदापि विपर्ययं Nidāgha's case is an example of misapprehension.
ṛbhuḥ paramakaruṇayā nidāghasya gṛhametya bahudhā taṃ bodhayitvā nirjagāma /	Out of exceeding compassion Rbhu went to Nidāgha's place and left after convincing him variously.
buddhe'pi tadupadiṣṭe vastunyaśraddadhāno nidāghaḥ karmāṇyeva paramapuruṣārthaheturiti viparyayaṃ prāpya karmānuṣṭhāne yathāpūrvaṃ pravṛttaḥ /	Nidāgha, although convinced, disbelieving in the reality of the thing instructed, misapprehending rituals to be the only means to the supreme aim of life, went on with the observance of rituals as before.
so'pi śiṣyasya na jahau /	Even then he did not give up the opposite understanding.
tṛtīyena tu bodhanena viparyayaṃ parityajya viśrāntimalabhata /	But on the third instruction, obviating the misapprehension, he attained tranquillity .
